sub_topic: Identifying the Eulerian and Hamiltonian paths in a graph.
message_1:
Consider the following undirected graph with vertices labeled from A to G and edge weights given in the parentheses. Determine whether or not this graph contains an Eulerian path and a Hamiltonian path, and if so, provide the respective path(s).
 
    (4) A ----- B (2)
    |         / | \
    |      /    |   \
    |   /       |      \
   (3) C --------D-----E (5)
           \           |
              \       |              
                  \  |(4)   
                    F-------G (1)
message_2:
An Eulerian path is a path in a graph that visits every edge exactly once. A graph has an Eulerian path if and only if it has at most two vertices with an odd degree.

Degree of each vertex:
A: 2
B: 4
C: 3
D: 4
E: 3
F: 3
G: 1

There are 5 vertices with an odd degree, so there is no Eulerian path in this graph.

A Hamiltonian path is a path in a graph that visits every vertex exactly once. Determining whether a graph has a Hamiltonian path is an NP-complete problem, so there is no efficient algorithm to solve it. However, since this graph is small, we can try to find a Hamiltonian path manually.

One possible Hamiltonian path is: A - C - D - B - E - F - G

So, this graph does have a Hamiltonian path.
